title: The Study of Music
description: This course explores music as a fundamental human practice, and introduces the study of music as central to broader humanistic inquiry. By engaging with styles and performance practices from various regions and historical eras, students will develop an understanding of the diverse ways in which music intersects with human experience, culture, and history. To this end, the course employs an issue-based approach. The first several class sessions deal with fundamental questions about music, such as: What is music? How do musical sounds communicate meaning? What are the relationships between musical sounds, contexts, listening habits, and human behavior? How and why do scholars study music? The remainder of the semester is devoted to particular case studies that explore music’s relationship to other realms including politics, religion, identity, and globalization. The class is structured around interactive lectures, demonstrations, discussion, and in-class group activities. No prior musical background or training is required.
outcome: Students will: Become familiar with a broad range of musics and performance practices from diverse geographical locations and historical eras Cultivate frameworks for understanding and analyzing music as a social and cultural practice Develop fundamental skills in music research—how to read, listen, think, and write critically about music Learn to listen critically and closely, and identify musical sounds and structures through in-depth audition and discussion of musical examples Become familiar with diverse academic approaches to the study of music
syllabus: Course syllabus will vary from semester to semester, and will be distributed by the professor teaching the course at the start of the term. Topics may include:  Introduction to the Course: Music Fundamentals Defining “Music” Musical Instruments: The Cultural Materiality of Music Musical Notations: Conservation, Communication, Conception Academic Approaches to the Study of Music: Ethnomusicology, Historical Musicology, and Music Theory Performance and Pedagogy Music, Ideology, and Politics Music, Identity, and Ethnicity Music, Migration, and Mobility Music, Ritual, Religion, and Spirituality Popular Music and Culture Music and Globalization

title: Analysis and Performance
description: This course offers upper undergraduates the opportunity to explore the interactions between analysis and performance in tonal music. Factors that affect interpretative decisions such as the choice of editions, stylistic competency, historical performance practice, generic and formal expectations, rhythmic and metrical awareness, harmonic sensitivity and structural understanding will be addressed in turn. Concepts will be introduced primarily by way of scores and recordings, and readings will also be assigned where appropriate. Students should be prepared to engage in music making (singing and/or playing). This is a recommended course for performance stream students and an elective for others.
outcome: Upon successfully completing this course, students will be expected to demonstrate:  1. Analytical competence for tonal music in different styles, genres and periods;  2. Awareness of the main issues and concerns surrounding the performance of different repertoires;  3. Familiarity with the factors informing musical interpretation and the ways in which these may be communicated to the audience; 4. Ability to apply the concepts learnt to their own performance and/or research.

title: Music Performer’s Issues
description: What does it take for performers to deliver a secure performance on stage? Why can’t one deliver a successful performance despite endless hours of practice? Do performers still want to perform live when everybody has free access to world-class concerts online? This course examines challenges faced by performers and provides practical advices on issues including practice strategies, mental imagining, memorization, motivation, performance anxiety, injury prevention, collaboration among musicians, and creativity in music performance. Along with lectures on performers’ issues, students will engage in the study of their chosen repertoire and participate in discussion on related stylistic features and performance practice. All that cumulates into their final projects, interactive talk-performances where performers help audience members to listen, perform, create, and reflect in ways that heighten their musical perceptions.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: Understand and articulate mainstream ideas of concepts, techniques, methods, and experiences of music performers, pedagogues, psychologists, and researchers. Reflect in depth about critical similarities, differences, and intersections between their own and others’ perception in music performing and learning so as to demonstrate a deepening or transformation of original perspectives. Demonstrate competency in planning, preparing, and delivering effective interactive performance and evaluation strategies. Acquire and apply the necessary knowledge and skills needed to effectively deliver music performance.
syllabus: Topics will include practice behaviour and retention, mental imaging, memorization concepts and strategies, motivation, performance anxiety, injury prevention, collaborative techniques and interaction in rehearsals, creativity in music performance, interacting and engaging with the audience, interaction and engaging with the audience, interactive talk-performance delivery.

requirements: Pre-requisite(s): MUSC2872 and MUSC2882 or permission by the instructor.
description: The course provides a grounding in approaches to thinking and writing about popular music critically, with some theoretical and musicological background in musical, historical, and cultural issues. title: Traditional Musical Culture in China
requirements: For MA Music
description: Covering significant issues and topics in the study of Chinese music history, this course focuses on traditional Chinese music and its relevance to modern society. It aims to expose students to both Chinese and international scholarship by means of an up-to-date discussion of the historiography of Chinese music.
outcome: • Cover significant issues and topics in traditional Chinese musical culture • Reinforce and expand critical insight from a wide spectrum of perspectives • Demonstrate a postgraduate level of competence in critical judgments about traditional Chinese music

title: Musical Culture in Contemporary China
requirements: For MA Music
description: Focusing on the modernization, westernization and globalization faced by the Chinese since the early 20th century, this course deals with the survival, positioning and cultural environment of Chinese music. Based on recent scholarly discourse in China and the West, the course takes a multi-disciplinary approach to the study of contemporary Chinese music.

title: Western Opera & Vocal Literature
requirements: For MA Music
description: A survey of Western opera and related vocal literature from Baroque to the present. Emphasis on exploring historical, stylistic, and aesthetic aspects of representative works and their leading composers through the perspectives of composer, performer, and audience. The classes will explore various opera scenes, songs and other vocal repertoire and their associated performance practice through historical and analytical reading, discussion and analysis of recorded performances, score reading, and source study. Along with weekly lectures, students participate in in-class discussions, complete class exercises, and work towards their final project presentations combining scholarly work and practical work.
outcome: • Reinforce and expand awareness of significant operatic and other vocal genres, performance practices, and musical conventions of the historical periods studied • Demonstrate a postgraduate level of competence in critical judgments about Western vocal music
syllabus: This course will provide a history of Western opera, starting from its origin, leading into the twentieth centuries; as well as looking into the development of chamber and solo vocal literature. Opera has been for four hundred years one of the world's most extraordinary and enthralling artistic mediums, representing human passions with astonishing power and drama. The course will introduce various social, political, and literary contexts of operas and related vocal literature, examine their national traditions, and encounter the debates and polemics that have accompanied the development of the art forms throughout its history. Consideration will also be given to issues of performance past and present. Works by the greatest composers are included, from Monteverdi, Bach, Mozart, Schumann, Rossini, Verdi, and Wagner, to Puccini, Debussy, Berg, and Shostakovich. Students will gain detailed knowledge of and skills in the following areas: major composers and core repertoire of Western opera and vocal music relationships between operatic styles and their historical contexts presentation of new material as preparation for future teaching independent study as the foundation of research in the field of musicology  a critical essay and presentation on a selected topic serve as the final project
